message.content:
We start by interpreting “X is Y’s descendant” to mean that X comes later in the lineage than Y. Using this, let’s translate the given statements:

• “Nancy is Julie’s descendant” → Julie is an ancestor of Nancy.
• “Julie is Edward’s descendant” → Edward is an ancestor of Julie (and thus Nancy).
• “Christopher is Edward’s ancestor” → Christopher is an ancestor of Edward.
• “Terry is Christopher’s ancestor” → Terry is an ancestor of Christopher.
• “Catherine is Terry’s descendant” → Terry is an ancestor of Catherine.
• “Frank is Catherine’s descendant” → Catherine is an ancestor of Frank.
• “Frank is Roger’s ancestor” → Frank is an ancestor of Roger.

So we can form two chains:

Chain 1:
 Terry → Christopher → Edward → Julie → Nancy

Chain 2:
 Terry → Catherine → Frank → Roger

Because both chains start with Terry (or have some common ancestor in the larger tree), Nancy and Roger share at least Terry as a common ancestor. There is no indication that either is the descendant or ancestor of the other. Therefore, the correct relationship is that Roger and Nancy share a common ancestor.

<ANSWER>3</ANSWER>
